title-group.article-title: Microtubule curling as an efficient readout to uncover fundamental concepts of axonal cell biology

abstract.p: In neurodegeneration, axons tend to be prime lesion sites. Axons are the slender, up-to-meter-long processes of nerve cells that essentially wire nervous systems. These delicate structures must survive for an organism’s lifetime. Their long-term maintenance requires complex cell biology to be locally present in axons, and this depends on the steady supply with organelles and materials. These are delivered by motor protein-driven axonal transport, which uses continuous bundles of MTs as highways that run interrupted from the cell body to the axon tip. By studying the regulation of these bundles in our past work, we identified many conditions in which microtubules become severely disorganised, a phenotype expected to be detrimental for axons. Further work on these conditions led us to propose the ‘dependency cycle of local axon homeostasis’ model explaining how aberration of different cell biological processes can lead to one common outcome – as is the case in neurodegeneration. Here we put this model to the test. Through live imaging we trace the origins and time course of microtubule disorganisation in normal and mutant neurons, and our findings confirm key mechanisms proposed in our model. Combining published data with the re-analysis and new investigation of 105 gene deficiencies from a wide range of cell biological contexts, we find that ~40% cause the shared microtubule disorganisation phenotype, thus clearly corroborating a key idea of the cycle. Through probing the phenotypes of 18 genes for ROS involvement, we find them to correctly classify into a mechanical ROS-independent versus a physiological ROS-dependent group, providing strong support for a central aspect of the dependency model.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Neurodegenerative disorders are an increasing socioeconomic burden to modern ageing societies causing enormous suffering to affected individuals (Steinmetz et al., 2024). However, due to the enormous complexity of neuronal cell biology, the underlying pathological processes remain little understood posing an obstacle to finding cures. A potential way to narrow down the task is to focus on nerve fibres (aka axons), which are prime lesion sites in many neurodegenerative diseases (Coleman and Höke, 2020; Prokop, 2021a; Smith et al., 2023). Axons are the up-to-meter-long cable-like protrusions of neurons that wire nervous systems and are therefore indispensable for information flow. These delicate structures are constantly exposed to intracellular and often also extracellular mechanical challenges, yet they can usually not be replaced and must survive for an organism’s lifetime - up to a century in humans. Consequently, ~40% of axons are lost during normal ageing in mammals (Adalbert and Coleman, 2012; Calkins, 2013; Marner et al., 2003), and even more in neurodegeneration. A key question therefore is how axons can survive long-term, often more than a meter away from their cell bodies.

The key prerequisite for long-term maintenance is the presence, in axons, of essential cell biological components including organelles, endomembrane systems, cytoskeleton, metabolism, proteostasis and signalling mechanisms, which jointly arrange into a network of local homeostasis (Smith et al., 2023). Maintaining this homeostasis requires the transport and movement of organelles and materials from and to the cell body or to sites of acute need; this transport is mediated by molecular motors moving along microtubules (MTs) as their highways which are arranged into bundles that run uninterrupted from the neuronal cell bodies to axon tips (Guedes-Dias and Holzbaur, 2019; Guillaud et al., 2020; Prokop, 2020; Sleigh et al., 2019). In this way, MT bundles throw a lifeline to axons, but become their Achilles heels if disrupted.

Our work of the last ~20 years has therefore been focussed on the role and regulation of MTs in axons using Drosophila neurons as a standardised cellular model. Fly neurons enabled us to study a wide range of genes known to regulate MTs or other relevant cell biological processes. Since all these studies are being carried out in one consistent model, phenotypes can be easily classified highlighting differences and commonalities. One often observed, shared phenotype is the deterioration of axonal bundles into areas where MTs form arrangements of disordered curling (Fig.1). We recently proposed the ‘dependency cycle of local axon homeostasis’ as a model that can explain the phenomenon of MT-curling and may even help to conceptualise processes of axonal degeneration (Fig.2; Hahn et al., 2019; Prokop, 2021a; Shields et al., 2024; Smith et al., 2023).

The dependency cycle proposes that axonal transport is beneficial for axon maintenance (‘1’ and ‘2’ in Fig.2), but transport motors impose mechanical forces that can lead to damage including MT-curling (‘3’ in Fig.2). This damage is counter-balanced through repair or replacement of MTs performed by MT-binding proteins (‘4’ in Fig.2), thus establishing ‘structural homeostasis’. This homeostasis is perturbed by hyperactivation of motors (Liew et al., 2025) or loss of MTBPs involved in bundle maintenance (Hahn et al., 2021). Importantly, the bundle maintenance machinery is itself dependent on axonal transport which provides the necessary materials, factors and the right physiological conditions (‘5’ in Fig.2). Disturbance of axonal transport, but also the dysfunction of certain organelles, can derail ‘physiological homeostasis’ prone to generate oxidative stress which has recently been shown to be a strong inducer of MT-curling (Liew et al., 2025; Murray-Cors et al., 2025; Shields et al., 2025), thus establishing a circular relationship where MTs are both up- and downstream of transport. This circular relationship would predict that many aspects of axonal cell biology can lead to cycle collapse, as is similarly the case in neurodegenerative disorders (Shields et al., 2024; Smith et al., 2023). However, although existing work is so far consistent with the ‘dependency cycle of local axon homeostasis’, the model remains mechanistically unrefined and hypothetical.

Here we provide new data that provide fundamental understanding of MT-curling as a phenomenon and provide a comprehensive analysis of a wide range of different factors that make up the dependency cycle. Our findings corroborate and complement existing data and lend important new support to the model.

sec.title: Live imaging reveals reduced reversibility of MT-curling events in mutant neurons
sec.p: Disorganised MT-curling in axons is a potential pathological indicator not only in cultured Drosophila neurons, but has likewise been observed in vivo in the fly brain (Hahn et al., 2021; Okenve-Ramos et al., 2024; Qu et al., 2019) and in axons of vertebrate and mammalian neurons (Hahn et al., 2019; Prokop, 2021a; Smith et al., 2023; see Discussion). To gain a better understanding of disorganised MT-curling we studied the origin and timeline of curling events. For this, we carried out live-imaging experiments using either laser scanning or spinning disc microscopy of primary neurons, where MTs were labelled either with mCherry-tagged Jupiter (a MT-binding protein associating with MT lattices; Karpova et al., 2006) or with the live-dye SiR-tubulin (Lukinavičius et al., 2014). We used wild-type neurons, and three different loss-of-function mutant alleles of genes known to cause severe MT-curling in fixed preparations (Tab.S1): (1) the actin-MT crosslinking factor Short stop (allele used: shot3; Sánchez-Soriano et al., 2009), (2) the MT plus end-associating factor Eb1 (Eb104524; Hahn et al., 2021) and (3) the kinesin-1-associated protein Kinesin light chain (Klc8ex94). Shot and Eb1 are both involved in MT bundle maintenance (Qu et al., 2022; ‘M1’ in Fig.2, ‘1, 3a and 4’ in Fig.3), whereas Klc is required for the inactivation of the Kinesin heavy chain motor protein (‘11’ in Fig.3) with its functional loss causing motor hyperactivation (Liew et al., 2025).

Live imaging started 2 hrs after plating of the neurons and continued for up to 22 hrs (Fig.4). During the entire imaging period, neurons of all four genotypes displayed ~1.3 initiation events of disorganisation along their axons (Fig.4A). Also the median time of first occurrence of any area of disorganisation was only mildly different between genotypes: it ranged from 201 to 362 min across genotypes, with wild-type having a bias for later and shot3 and Klc8ex94 for earlier onset (Fig.4B); onset could be at the very start of imaging, but also up to ~1,100 minutes later in wild-type and Eb104524 mutant neurons, and ~500 to 700 minutes in shot3 and Klc8ex94 mutant neurons - but such late events were rare outliers (Fig.4B). MT-curling events were initiated (i) close to the soma, (ii) along the axon shaft, (iii) at axonal branch points or (iv) in growth cones at axon tips (Figs.4C, S1). These areas might provide the necessary space for individual MTs to curl which would otherwise be prevented by plasma membrane rigidity. In agreement with this hypothesis, most curling events for all four genotypes initiated in growth cones at axon tips which are usually the most spacious axon compartment (Figs.4C, S1E,F).

Whereas these parameters appeared rather similar across genotypes, clear distinctions were observed when monitoring the area of individual MT-curling events over time, from the timepoint of their initiation to the end of the documentation period (Fig.4D): in wild-type neurons, areas of disorganisation were clearly kept in check and could even be reversed to the default bundled MT state. In contrast, shot3 and Eb104524 mutant neurons showed a strong and significant trend where areas of disorganisation, once seeded, continued to grow steadily bigger; reversal was hardly ever seen (Fig.4D). The same trend was true for Klc8ex94 mutant neurons, although it was far less pronounced, which might reflect the use of SiRtub rather than Jupiter to label MTs, the potential maternal rescue of Klc, or the very different function of Klc compared to Shot and Eb1 (see Discussion).

Taken together, we observed no difference in initiation frequency of MT-curling between genotypes, and all showed a clear preference for onset in growth cones. However, only in neurons lacking MTBPs the curling persisted for the entire imaging period. These findings agree with our hypothesis of constant bias to initiate MT-curling (potentially reflecting motor activity), kept in check by the action of MTBPs - but overwhelmed if motors are hyperactivated (Klc) or maintenance factors absent (Shot, Eb1; see Discussion for detail).

sec.title: Large-scale analyses reveal MT-curling in ~40% of genetic loss-of-function conditions
sec.p: To dissect mechanisms of MT-curl induction genetically, we assessed MT-curling phenotypes of a wide range of mutant conditions, using the MT disorganisation index (MDI; see Methods) for quantification. Here we present data from 180 individual experiments covering the functional manipulation of 105 genes (Tab.S1; Fig.2). Half of these experiments were collated from previously published work (source provided before slash in the last column of Tab.S1), and the other half either involved new experiments or the re-analysis of data or images from previous experiments that had not been analysed to our common standards, some dating back to 2009 (see Methods; behind slash in last column of Tab.S1). As indicated in Tab.S1, measurements were obtained using Drosophila primary neurons extracted from whole embryos (‘e’ in Tab.S1) and in some cases from larval brains (‘L’; Prokop et al., 2012; Voelzmann and Sánchez-Soriano, 2022). In the case of homozygous lethal mutations, the heterozygous mothers often deposit wild-type gene product in the eggs referred to as maternal contribution, which may persist into larval stages (Roote and Prokop, 2013). Since maternal contribution can mask phenotypes in embryo-derived neurons, it needs to be depleted by culturing cells for several days in vitro (eDIV), or by keeping them in a centrifuge tube for several days followed by culturing for usually 1DIV (‘pre’ in Tab.S1; Prokop et al., 2012). Notably, conclusions about MT-curling phenotypes were found to be comparable regardless of the culture strategy used, as long as maternal contribution was depleted (Alves-Silva et al., 2012; Hahn et al., 2021; Liew et al., 2025).

Of the 105 genes for which functional loss or gain was assessed (most validated with independent genetic tools; Tab.S1), an astonishing ~40% displayed MT curling (Fig.2). To spot rules or patterns in this unprecedented data set, we grouped genes into functional classes and assigned them to adequate functional positions around the dependency cycle (Fig.2). They comprise tubulins and tubulin chaperones or regulators (T1-T3), actin regulators (A1-A4), MT-binding proteins (MTBPs; M1-M4), mitotic kinesins (Mk), transport motor proteins (Mo1-3; see legend for details), cargo linkers (L), genes regulating organelles (O1-3), as well as enzymes (E1,2). When applying this classification and lining groups up to their appropriate position around the dependency cycle (Fig.2), it becomes obvious that dysfunction of many very different aspects of axonal cell biology can cause the same MT-curling phenotype, consistent with the idea that the dependency cycle can be broken in any position to cause a shared or common disease outcome.

sec.title: Loss of actin regulators tends to reduce MT-curling
sec.p: As illustrated by the white and blue colour code in Fig.2, there are three groups of genes where loss of function mostly fails to induce MT-curling or even reduces curling. This is the case for a fraction of mitochondrial factors (right column of ‘O3’ in Fig.2), actin regulators (‘A2-5’) and tubulin regulators (‘T1-3’). The analyses of the mitochondrial factors were reported and discussed previously (Murray-Cors et al., 2025). They comprise six important regulators of mitochondrial fission, fusion and cristae formation, suggesting that mitochondrial contortion observed upon their loss is well-buffered by mechanisms protecting from oxidative stress, at least during the assessed period of 5 days.

For actin regulators, we propose two possible explanations based on findings from previous publications. Firstly, some actin regulators contribute to the formation of cortical actin rings in the axon shaft; these rings seem to promote MT polymerisation in axons (‘3d’ in Fig.3), and the degree of ring loss correlated with reduced MT-curling (Qu et al., 2017). Reduced MT polymerisation might also have a negative effect on axon growth, and our data for actin ring-destabilising conditions (the actin-destabilising drug cytochalasin D, the actin-stabiliser Hts/ADDUCIN or the ring connector β-Spectrin; Qu et al., 2017) agree with this notion (Fig.S2).

The second actin-dependent mechanism relates to the fact that mutations in many actin regulators suppresses the formation of large hand-shaped growth cones (Gonçalves-Pimentel et al., 2011; Qu et al., 2022; Sánchez-Soriano et al., 2010). As discussed before, growth cones are the major initiation sites for MT-curling events (Fig.4C), and keeping their shape narrow likely hinders the curling of individual MTs, explaining the reduction in MDI (Fig.5). Instead, all MTs extend straight which leads to enhanced axon growth (Gonçalves-Pimentel et al., 2011; Qu et al., 2022; Sánchez-Soriano et al., 2010) and likely explains the high proportion of actin regulator mutations causing axon elongation (Fig.5).

Among the actin regulators, Lrch deficiency was not described before and stands out as the most severe case of axon elongation (Fig.5); it was rescued by GFP::Lrch expression, which we found to localise throughout axons, not obviously associated with F-actin (Fig.S3). LRCH family members are the only proteins combining actin-binding calponin-homology domains with leucin-rich repeats existing as four paralogues in mammals and a single gene in Drosophila (Rivière et al., 2020). In humans, LRCH family members feature in various contexts, but the underlying mechanisms are little understood (Rivière et al., 2020). In Drosophila, Lrch is expressed in the nervous system (flybase.org, FBgn0032633), its loss is a viable condition which causes female sterility, shortens lifespan and affects cellular processes of mitosis and cell division in S2 cells (Foussard et al., 2010). Drosophila primary neurons might provide a promising model for its study.

Taken together, actin regulators seem to promote MT polymerisation in axon shafts (potentially enhancing axon growth and favouring MT-curling) but also growth cone enlargement (slowing down axon growth but also favouring MT-curling). This can explain the consistent reduction in MT-curling across actin regulator deficiencies, but also the mixed outcomes for axon elongation (Fig.5).

sec.title: Losses of tubulins or tubulin chaperones cause reduced axon length and MT curling
sec.p: The third group of gene deficiencies primarily causing no or reduced MT-curling often combined with reduced axon growth are the regulators involved in tubulin provision or MT nucleation (‘T1-T3’ in Fig.2; Hahn et al., 2021; Qu et al., 2017). These include functional losses of the genes αtub84B (encoding α1-tubulin), γTub23C (essential for MT nucleation), and of genes encoding members of the CCT and TBC chaperone complexes (Pinho-Correia and Prokop, 2023; Voelzmann et al., 2016; Fig.S4). Only CCT1 and TBCD seem to be exceptions (Fig.6), and these ‘escapers’ might be explained through chaperone-independent functions of individual members of the CCT and the TBC complexes (Pinho-Correia and Prokop, 2023). For example, the isolated substrate-binding apical domain of Saccharomyces TPC1/CCT1 (ApiCCT1; conserved in fly and human: Fig.S4) was shown to prevent pathological protein aggregates in an ATP-independent manner and revert neuronal atrophy in mouse Huntington’s disease models (Sontag et al., 2013; Tam et al., 2006; Zhao et al., 2016).

Also loss of Stathmin (Stai; orthologous to STMN) causes a reduction in MT-curling and axon growth, comparable to tubulin chaperone deficiencies (Fig.6 and ‘T2’ in Fig.2); shorter axons are also observed upon loss of the mammalian orthologue STMN2 (aka SCG10; Manna et al., 2007). Our quantitative RT-PCR analyses of wild-type larval CNSs revealed α1- (αTub84B) and β1-tubulin (βTub56D) as the by far highest expressed isotypes in neuronal tissues (Fig.S5E), as is in agreement with existing micro array analyses (‘FlyAtlas2’: motif.mvls.gla.ac.uk/FlyAtlas2; Krause et al., 2021) and RNAseq data (‘modEncode’: www.modencode.org/publications/about/index.shtml; Celniker et al., 2009). In Stai-deficient CNSs, the mRNAs of both these tubulins were reduced by ~50% or more, and the same was true for the far less abundant β3-tubulin (β-Tub60D; Fig.S5D). These reductions agree with previous data for tubulin mRNA and proteins extracted from whole stai mutant specimens (Duncan et al., 2013; Fletcher and Rørth, 2007). They might be owed to roles of Stai in protecting tubulin pools from auto-inhibitory regulation of its own biogenesis, as discussed elsewhere (‘3c’ in Fig.3; Duncan et al., 2013; Pinho-Correia and Prokop, 2023; Sellin et al., 2008; Voelzmann et al., 2016). This said, recent reports suggest that not all roles of Stathmins during axon growth regulation involve tubulin-binding (Beccari et al., 2025).

Given the enormous quantities of tubulins required during axon growth, one might expect that the host of tubulins is produced locally in axons (Pinho-Correia, 2023). Accordingly, our spot-checks of factors required for tubulin biogenesis revealed their presence in axons, including tubulin mRNAs, the ribosomal component Rpl10, the P-body component Me31B and the chaperones Pfdn2, Tbcb and Tbce (Fig.S6). Furthermore, puromycin assays suggest local translation to take place in axons (Fig.S6F-I). However, further calculations based on our data and the literature would suggest that local production of tubulins in axons is highly insufficient to serve the tubulin demand in growing axons, raising an important aspect that will need more attention in future research (details in Fig.S6E and its legend).

Taken together, our results might suggest that increased MT nucleation and polymerisation promote axon growth but also heighten the risk for MT-curling (as also suggested by loss of actin regulators; see above), likely through the enhanced probability of accidental off-track extensions of MTs which must therefore be counterbalanced through guidance and elimination mechanisms (‘2’, ‘4’, ‘6’, ‘12’ in Fig.3; see Discussion).

sec.title: Roles of other MT-binding proteins in the context of MT-curling
sec.p: Some further findings deserve to be highlighted here. Firstly, K40-acetylation of α-tubulin is considered to render MTs more stable, but also more flexible and less prone to breakage (Eshun-Wilson et al., 2019; Li and Yang, 2015; Portran et al., 2017; Xu et al., 2017). In Arabidopsis, K40A substitution was shown to cause MT aberrations (Xiong et al., 2013). K40 acetylation might therefore be important during MT-curling, and Drosophila neurons are ideal to test this possibility because they express almost exclusively α1-tubulin (Fig.S5E). We capitalised on this by assessing neurons homozygous for the viable mutant alleles αTub84BK40R (mimicking the non-acetylated state) and αTub84BK40Q (mimicking the acetylated state). Both alleles suppressed immunoreactivity of the 6-11-B1 antibody (specific for K40 acetylation; Piperno and Fuller, 1985 ; Fig.S10C-D’) but caused no obvious changes in MT-curling or axon length at 3 DIV (Tab.S1, ‘T3’ in Fig.2). This agrees with findings of mild phenotypes for these K40 mutations in Drosophila neurons in vivo (Jenkins et al., 2017) as well as in other model organisms (Prokop, 2022; see Discussion). Depletion of Atat, the enzyme responsible for K40 acetylation (Luo et al., 2025) also caused absence of 6-11-B1 immunoreactivity (Fig.S10B), but it caused a modest MT-curling phenotypes (Tab.S1, ‘T3’ in Fig.2). This might align with reports of MT damage observed in ATAT1-deficient mouse embryonic fibroblasts (Xu et al., 2017), potentially suggesting that Atat has functions beyond K40 (see Discussion).

Secondly, we assessed loss of function of the MT-severing AAA ATPases Spastin and Katanin (‘M3’ in Fig.2; McNally and Roll-Mecak, 2018). Spastin deficiency was shown to cause axonal swellings with curled MTs in mouse neurons (Fassier et al., 2013; Tarrade et al., 2006), but our rigorous testing of functional loss of fly Spastin failed to reveal any such phenotypes in Drosophila primary neurons; we could also not detect obvious aberrations of the endoplasmic reticulum as a second target of Spastin-mediated regulation (Öztürk et al., 2020; Tab.S1, Fig.S7C,D). Instead, loss of the catalytic Katanin subunit Kat60 caused severe MT curling (Fig.S7), which was not enhanced in Kat6017A spas575 double-mutant neurons (Fig.S7), suggesting that Spas and Kat60 are not functionally redundant. In plants, Katanin severs MTs that cross each other at steep angle (McNally and Roll-Mecak, 2018; Vemu et al., 2018; Wang et al., 2017). This would represent a powerful quality control mechanism eliminating MTs that cross each other in curled areas (‘6’ in Fig.3), thus acting complementary to cortical MT collapse through Efa6 (‘2’ in Fig.3). Alternative explanations may involve the interaction of Katanin with CAMSAP (Jiang et al., 2018) at sites of MT damage (Zhang et al., 2023) or at MT minus ends (Akhmanova, 2018; Akhmanova and Steinmetz, 2015; Dong et al., 2017), which might also contribute to the anchorage of MT minus ends to the cell cortex (‘1’ in Fig.3; Nashchekin et al., 2016; Ning et al., 2016; Noordstra et al., 2016).

Thirdly, we analysed mitotic kinesins which were originally described to slide apart antiparallel MTs in mitotic spindles and were later found to be present also in axons where MTs are organised in parallel fashion and can act as MT cross-linkers stopping the motor-driven transport of MT fragments (Guha et al., 2021). Our analyses of the deficiencies of 5 different mitotic kinesins revealed MT-curling phenotypes for all of them, which were most robust for two kinesin-6 family members (Pavarotti/KIF23, Subito/KIF20A) and the kinesin-14 Ncd/KIFC1 (Fig.S8, Tab.S1, ‘MK’ in Fig.2). We also tested expression of the immobile PavDEAD::GFP rigour-mutant variant (Minestrini et al., 2002) which tightly decorated axonal MTs typical of rigour mutants (Fig.S8C; Blangy et al., 1998; Klumpp et al., 2003; Minestrini et al., 2002; Nakata and Hirokawa, 1995), and caused severe MT-curling potentially by acting as a dominant-negative in Pavarotti homodimers (Fig.S8A,D; Tab.1).

For the mammalian mitotic kinesins KIF11, KIF15 and KIF1C/Ncd it was shown that they can simultaneously step on two parallel MTs and bundle them in vitro (Drechsler and McAinsh, 2016; Kapitein et al., 2005; Oladipo et al., 2007; Tao et al., 2006). We suggest therefore that Pavarotti and Subito might walk anterogradely along two parallel MTs, thus zipping them together; this would be a potential way to dynamically stabilise MT bundles, especially behind large, transported cargoes, to prevent MT buckling as a potential seed for curling (‘7’ in Fig.3; Bicek et al., 2009). Ncd as a minus end-directed mitotic kinesin could do the same during retrograde transport (Cai et al., 2009; She and Yang, 2017; Wendt et al., 2002).

sec.title: Trolox application provides further support for the dual homeostasis hypothesis
sec.p: As explained in the Introduction, axonal MT-curling can be triggered by disturbing two different forms of homeostasis: firstly, ‘physiological homeostasis’ can be affected through wrong positioning or dysfunction of organelles which triggers harmful ROS as an indirect cause for MT-curling; secondly, ‘mechanical homeostasis’ can be affected through direct, ROS-independent curl induction caused by an imbalance between motor forces and the maintenance action of MT-binding proteins (Fig.7B). To assess whether curl-induction is ROS-independent (suggesting mechanical dyshomeostasis) or mediated by ROS (suggesting physiological dyshomeostasis), we applied Trolox (6-hydroxy-2,5,7,8-tetramethylchroman-2-carboxylic acid). Trolox inhibits fatty acid peroxidation and quenches singlet oxygen and superoxide, thus acting as an antioxidant beneficial in many cell systems including neuronal models of neurodegeneration (Chow et al., 1994; Giordano et al., 2020; Janc and Müller, 2014).

In previous work, the application of Trolox has started to paint a consistent picture of curl-inducing conditions: the hyperactivation of transport motors does not involve ROS (red dots/font in Fig.7), whereas deficient axonal transport of at least mitochondria and lysosomes (the organelles assessed so far; black in Fig.7), mitochondrial dysfunction (green) or the loss of the cytoplasmic enzyme Sod1 are all ROS-inducing (grey; Liew et al., 2025; Murray-Cors et al., 2025; Shields et al., 2025). Here we assessed further MT-curl-inducing conditions.

As factors expected to cause ROS-independent MT-curling we chose three candidates: the actin-MT cross-linker Shot guides polymerising MTs or anchors their minus ends (‘1’ and ‘4’ in Fig.3; Qu et al., 2022); the mitotic kinesin Pavarotti might act as MT-cross-linker (see above; Fig.S8, ‘7’ in Fig.3); the severing protein Katanin60 might sever criss-crossing MTs or contribute during the anchoring of MT minus ends (see above; Fig.S7; ‘1’ and ‘6’ in Fig. 3). In agreement with these proposed functions, all three factors were not rescued upon Trolox application (Figs. 7, 8A-C). With respect to potential ROS-dependent candidates, we assessed loss of ER-regulating factors which were all MT-curl-inducing (‘O1’ in Fig.2; Tab.S1). Of these, we tested MT-curling upon the combined loss of the ER morphogenesis regulators Rtnl1, ReepA and ReepB (Yalçin et al., 2017); we found that Trolox was able to completely rescue the phenotype (Fig.8D). We hypothesise that ROS induction upon dysregulation of ER morphogenesis likely relates to the important roles of ER in cross-regulating the functions of virtually all organelles in axons (Smith et al., 2023).

sec.title: The dependency cycle of local axon homeostasis develops into a robust model for neurodegeneration
sec.p: The key objectives of work presented here was to challenge the ‘dependency cycle of local axon homeostasis’ model as an attractive framework for axon maintenance and degeneration, and to increase our understanding of its mechanistic basis. We strongly feel that both these objectives were successfully addressed.

The key readout chosen here was MT-curling as a proxy for neurodegeneration: MT bundles provide the essential lifeline for axons, and their disturbance through MT-curling can be expected to turn them into the axons’ Archilles heels on path to degeneration (Okenve-Ramos et al., 2024; Prokop, 2021a; Smith et al., 2023). MT-curling is not an artifact observed in fly and vertebrate primary neurons but can also be observed in vivo in both Drosophila and primate brains (Fiala et al., 2007; Okenve-Ramos et al., 2024; Shields et al., 2025). In vivo, axons are often tightly fasciculated with a rigid cell surface expected to prevent curling in narrow axons shafts. However, opportunities to initiate curling might be provided by axonal blebbing observed in both flies and mammals in vivo (Ching and Sagasti, 2025; Okenve-Ramos et al., 2024; Shields et al., 2025), presenting a condition that would be analogous to curl initiation observed in spacious axonal segments in culture (Fig.4C).

Studying the functional loss of 105 genes, we clearly demonstrate that MT-curling can be caused by the functional loss of a wide range of genes linking to very different cell biological processes, and this mirrors the fact that a wide range of gene mutations can cause similar forms of axon degeneration in humans (Smith et al., 2023). Our data set is unprecedented not only with respect to the number of genes covered, but also because it was analysed to one common standard in one consistent neuronal model, enabling us to extract concepts by thinking across different genes and gene groups to. Collating these data occurred over a period of almost 20 years and was made possible through a highly efficient and standardised data management scheme enabling us to retrieve and re-analyse well-documented original image files, some dating back to 2009 (Prokop, 2021b).

Apart from showing the wide range of genes causing MT-curling, we also provide evidence in support of the binary homeostasis hypothesis which appears a helpful way to organise and classify curl-inducing conditions within the cycle model. The binary homeostasis hypothesis proposes that MT-curling can be triggered through mechanical dyshomeostasis which is ROS-independent, and physiological dyshomeostasis which causes harmful ROS as the essential curl-inducing trigger. So far, our past and present work brings together 18 different genetic conditions assessed with Trolox application, all of which were consistent with, and hence in support of, the binary homeostasis hypothesis (Fig.7).

In the context of mechanical homeostasis, MT-curling is proposed to be triggered by motor forces but kept in check by MT bundle maintenance machinery; this balance is derailed upon motor hyperactivation or deficient MT maintenance machinery. This view is also supported by our live imaging experiments where MT-curling is induced to equal amounts in normal and mutant neurons (Fig.4A) suggesting a common underlying cause (likely transport motor activity). However, MT-curling develops into large areas only under conditions of motor hyperactivation (Klc deficiency) or reduced MT bundle maintenance (Eb1, Shot; Fig.4D) supporting the idea that homeostasis depends on a balance between damaging force and maintenance. The curl-inducing mechanisms are less clear for physiological dyshomeostasis. On the one hand, we need to understand how aberrant organelle transport or organelle dysfunction can cause dyshomeostasis of ROS, and this has been discussed in detail elsewhere but remains speculation (Liew et al., 2025; Murray-Cors et al., 2025). On the other hand, we need to understand the mechanisms through which harmful ROS triggers MT-curling; this may involve the oxidation of MTs, of MT-binding proteins or of the upstream signalling molecules (see Discussions in Liew et al., 2025; Shields et al., 2025), and it may also involve ROS-induced blebbing of axons opening up space as an opportunity for curl induction (Mehta et al., 2025).

Finally, as mentioned before, MT-curling appears to be a conserved phenomenon, and the underlying mechanisms seem to have a high degree of similarity between fly and vertebrate neurons, as indicated by a gradually increasing amount of examples: (a) the curling observed upon loss of Dhc64C in Drosophila mirrors MT-curling upon DYNEIN knock-down in mouse neurons (Ahmad et al., 2006); (b) the shot mutant phenotype parallels curling observed upon knock-down of its orthologues ACF7 in mouse primary neurons and DYSTONIN in DRG mouse neurons in vivo (Eyer et al., 1998; Sánchez-Soriano et al., 2009); (c) application of the ROS inducer diethyl maleate (DEM) causes MT-curling in Drosophila and mouse cortical primary neurons alike (Liew, 2018); (d) combined partial loss of Tau, Msps and Eb1 functions causes curling in Drosophila neurons, as does combined partial knock-down of its orthologues in Xenopus primary neurons (Hahn et al., 2021); (e) expression of activated or non-activatable forms of GSK3β induces MT-curling in both fly and rat neurons (Voelzmann et al., 2024); (f) similar to hyperactivation of Khc in Drosophila, kinesin-1 hyperactivation with the kinesore peptide causes MT bending in rodent primary neurons (Patil et al., 2025).

A few other examples reveal molecular differences but potentially conserved concepts: (1) functional loss of mammalian JIP3/MAPK8IP3 (involved in lysosome transport) causes MT-curling in mouse primary neurons (Rafiq et al., 2022) but not deficiency of its fly homologue Sunday driver (involved in vesicular transport; Liew et al., 2025); instead, loss of Drosophila Arl8 (also involved in lysosome transport) causes strong curling (Liew et al., 2025); (2) loss of the severing protein Spastin causes MT-curling in mouse primary neurons but not in Drosophila, whereas loss of the severing protein Katanin does (Fig.S7; Fassier et al., 2013); (3) loss of the cortical collapse factor Efa6 in fly but not of its four mammalian orthologues causes MT-curling, but this function may have been taken over by the mammalian cortical collapse factor KIF21A (Qu et al., 2019).

Taken together, we strongly feel that we have provided data within the Drosophila neuron model that consolidate the concepts behind the dependency cycle, and there are strong indications that these concepts might apply also in axons of vertebrate neurons.

sec.title: New mechanisms emerged: potential to advance our understanding of axonal cell biology
sec.p: Two key themes have emerged from our work. On the one hand, work on several groups of genes hints at a critical role of mechanisms regulating MT-polymerisation which seem to perform a fine balancing act between promoting axon growth and driving the system into MT-curl induction. On the other hand, we may have revealed new mechanisms involved in MT-bundle maintenance.

With respect to MT polymerisation, the losses of both actin regulators required for cortical actin rings and the factors involved in tubulin biogenesis showed a trend to reduced or unaffected MT-curling, correlated with shorter axon growth (Figs.5, S2). Roles of the axonal actin cortex in promoting MT-polymerisation have been suggested previously (Qu et al., 2017; ‘3d’ in Fig.3), and it appears self-evident that reduced tubulin supply upon impaired tubulin biogenesis will likewise impact MT-curling. This said, previous work has shown that MT-nucleation is more sensitive to reduced tubulin levels than polymerisation (Hahn et al., 2021; Roostalu et al., 2020); accordingly, we find that EB1 comets at polymerising MT plus ends are only mildly shorter than in wild-type neurons, suggesting a modest net reduction in MT growth, in ways that still seem to permit safe Eb1-Shot-mediated guidance of MT extension (‘4’ in Fig.3); loosing this guidance would cause severely enhanced MT-curling (top 3 genes in ‘M1’ in Fig.2; Alves-Silva et al., 2012; Hahn et al., 2021; Qu et al., 2022). Instead, modest reduction in MT polymerisation might reduce the statistical chance of MTs extend off-track and leave the bundle organisation, thus providing less opportunity to seed potential curling events (‘2’ in Fig.3).

Our previous work had shown that such off-track projections of MTs can be eliminated by the cortical collapse factor Efa6 (and potentially KIF21A in vertebrates), acting as a quality control mechanism to reduce the chance of MT-curling (‘2’ in Fig.3; Qu et al., 2019). Here we propose Katanin as a further control mechanism acting directly within areas of disorganised curling (‘6’ in Fig.3). We base our hypothesis on knowledge from work in plants and in vitro showing that Katanin severs MTs which cross each other in steep angles (McNally and Roll-Mecak, 2018; Vemu et al., 2018; Wang et al., 2017) - ideal to eliminate MTs that fail to align into bundles.

Another central aspect of axonal cell biology are the mechanisms that stabilise MT bundle architecture against mechanical challenges posed by motor-driven cargo transport, which can be expected to cause buckling as a potential seed leading to MT-curling (yellow ‘8’ in Fig.3; Bicek et al., 2009). As argued previously, classical models of MT cross-linkers might be insufficient to deal with the dynamic challenges of this task (Lee and Brandt, 1992; Matus, 1991; Prokop, 2020). Here we propose mitotic kinesins as factors that might prevent buckling behind antero- and retrograde transport of heavy cargoes through ‘zippering’ action (‘7’ in Fig.3; see details in Results). The principal importance of mitotic kinesins for MT bundles has been clearly demonstrated by others before: KIFC1 (kinesin-14) is required for MT bundle integrity (Muralidharan and Baas, 2019), mammalian KIF23/MKLP1 or Drosophila Pavarotti (kinesin-6) down-regulate axon growth (Baas, 1999; Del Castillo et al., 2015; Joseph et al., 2021; Lu et al., 2013) whereas losses of KIF11 (kinesin-5) and KIF15 (kinesin-12) accelerate axon growth through regulating their microtubules (Dong et al., 2019; Liu et al., 2010; Lu et al., 2025; Myers and Baas, 2007; Nadar et al., 2012; Puthanveettil et al., 2024) and Klp61F was reported to regulate directional MT polymerisation in dendrites (Feng et al., 2021; Lin et al., 2012). Our observation of severe MT-curling upon loss of Ncd, Pav and Sub (‘Mk’ in Fig.2) to assess whether zippering is a potential underlying mechanism, capitalising on the versatile Drosophila primary neuron system.

Finally, our data might suggest that K40 acetylation of α-tubulin does not influence MT-curling, emphasised by the fact that the K40-mutant tubulins we used are highly penetrant, since they are unrivalled by other tubulin isotypes in Drosophila neurons (Fig.S5E). Similar K40 substitutions as used by us caused MT distortions in Arabidopsis (Xiong et al., 2013), but seem to have little impact in other organisms, such as Tetrahymena and Chlamydomonas (Gaertig et al., 1995; Kozminski et al., 1993), nematodes (Fukushige et al., 1999) as well as in vivo in Drosophila (Jenkins et al., 2017). In contrast, we find MT-curling upon loss of Atat which has been identified as the essential enzyme acetylating α-tubulins (Akella et al., 2010; Friedmann et al., 2012; Howes et al., 2014; Kalebic et al., 2013b) - although α-tubulin’s K40 was also shown to be tri-methylated by histone methyltransferase SET-domain-containing 2 (Park et al., 2016). Mice lacking ATAT1 are viable but display slight brain aberrations (Kim et al., 2013) and ATAT1-deficient mouse embryonic fibroblasts display MT damage (Xu et al., 2017). Atat may therefore display functions beyond K40 acetylation. On the one hand, ATAT1 was shown to regulate MT dynamics through mechanisms that are independent of its acetylation function (Kalebic et al., 2013a). On the other hand, many other acetylation sites on tubulins were demonstrated by independent mass spectrometry studies, three of them positioned inside the MT lumen as is the case for K40 (orange arrowheads in Fig.S10D). It might therefore be that K40 acetylation reflects a wider acetylation pattern across tubulins; in this scenario, K40 substitution would have only marginal effect, whereas Atat might contribute to the acetylation of further lysins causing a larger impact when deleted.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The genetic loss-of-function studies presented here were obtained in one standardised neuron system using consistent analysis strategies. They form an unprecedented pool of data to spot concepts across different classes of genes in a cellular system that is amenable to combinatorial genetics, i.e. providing efficient strategies to combine different gene manipulations in the same neurons. This provides a powerful system in which to unravel new mechanisms or concepts, test hypotheses and generate new ideas. As illustrated by the dependency cycle (Figs.2, 7B; Smith et al., 2023), the model has potential to generate new understanding that can inform research into human neurodegeneration. However, for this, translational studies into mammalian models will be a necessary and pivotal step. As discussed, various promising examples of molecular and conceptual conservation are existing already. But even if findings in vertebrate systems may turn out to deviate from the observations in flies, the fly-derived concepts may have been an essential facilitator by providing the key motivation for the respective translational research – and such contributions must not be underrated.

sec.title: Embryonic cultures
sec.p: Drosophila melanogaster primary neuronal cell cultures were prepared in accordance with the Prokop lab standard protocol (Prokop et al., 2012). Primary neurons were obtained either from embryos (either stage 12 or 17 depending on the experiment) or larval brains. For embryonic cultures, vials containing embryos were selected and dechorionated using bleach (diluted 1:1 with water) for 90 seconds. They were then poured through filter paper to collect the embryos and were then washed under tap water. Then, they were placed on agar plates under the fluorescent microscope to select for developmental stage (12 or 17) and/or against fluorescence from green balancer chromosomes. For each experiment, at least 15 embryos were selected. Embryos are usually selected at stage 12 (15-16h after egg lay at 21°C) the stage at which axonal growth sets in (Sánchez-Soriano, Tear et al. 2007), but can be collected at as late as stage 17 (15-16h after egg lay at 25°C).

After selection, the correct embryos were placed into the bottom of an microfuge tube. They were sterilised with 100μl 70% EtOH and then washed in 200μl Fresh Schneider’s Drosophila growth medium (Invitrogen). Next the culture medium was replaced by 100 μl dispersion medium and embryos were mechanically crushed with a pestle for cell dispersion, and incubated for 5 mins at 37°C. The Schneider’s growth medium was prepared as follows: Fetal bovine serum (20%, sterile-filtered, appropriate for cell culture, Sigma) was combined with Schneider’s Drosophila medium (Schneider, 1964) (Life Technologies) and 2 g/ml of human insulin from Sigma, St. Louis, Missouri (in a sterilised tube kept at 4 °C) was added and was filtered sterile. The culture media was divided into aliquots, refrigerated at -20°C for a maximum of four months, and then thawed at 37°C before use. The cell culture medium was filtered sterile a second time in a hood before use. The chemical dispersion medium is prepared as follows: 167 ml of autoclaved distilled water, 30 ml of 10x Hank’s Balanced Salt Solution (Gibco), 3 ml of penicillin/streptomycin solution (Gibco), and 0.01 g of phenylthiourea (Sigma) were combined. The mixture was then incubated for 30 minutes at 37°C, filtered, and stored as a stock solution at 4°C (ref as HBSS solution). Each working solution was made as follows: 0.1mg/ml of Collagenase (Worthington, cellsystems), 0.4 mg/ml Dispase (Roche) and 1:1000 penicilin/streptomycin (Gibco)] were added to the HBSS solution.

After 5 min incubation, 200μl of Schneider’s medium was added, followed by centrifugation at 750 rpm for 4 min and final dispersion (pipetting up and down) in Schneider’s medium (90μl for each 15 embryos invested) (Alves-Silva et al., 2012). Each culture chamber was then filled with 30 μl cell suspension (yielding the contents of 5 embryos per chamber) and closed with a Concanavalin A- (ConA) coated glass coverslip sealed at the edges with Vaseline. All chambers were left coverslip-facing down for 90 min at 26°C (for cells to settle and attach) and then turned upside-down (hanging-drop culture) and left incubating usually for 6h, 24h, or a specific number of days. When Gal4-driven knockdown constructs were used, cultures were kept at 29°C to increase the expression strength (Sánchez-Soriano, Gonçalves-Pimentel et al. 2010; Alves-Silva, Sánchez-Soriano et al. 2012).

sec.title: Larval cultures
sec.p: Larval cultures started with the collection of third instar larvae (~6/7 for cell cultures) with the right genotype (determined from their phenotype expression), and placed in a microfuge tube, where ethanol was then added to clean and sterilise the larvae. After, 1 mL of Schneider’s medium was added on an agar plate and then the selected larvae were submerged. Each larval brain was dissected under a light microscope and then placed into a microfuge tube with Fresh Schneider’s medium. The Schneider’s media was then discarded as per the next step. Dispersion medium was then added, and cells were incubated for 5 minutes. After this, the dispersion was stopped by adding an additional 200 μl of Schneider’s medium and centrifugation was carried out at 750 rpm for 4 min. The medium was then discarded via pipetting, and Schneider’s medium (at a volume of 30μl per culture/chamber) was again added, submerging and suspending the neurons by pipetting up and down. 30 μl of final solution was then dropped on to each culture chamber. The chambers were sealed with Vaseline and covered with ConA-coated glass coverslips. All chambers were left incubating at 26°C for 1.5 hours to allow neurons to attach to the coverslips and then left upturned for 1 day.

sec.title: Pre-cultures
sec.p: For pre-cultures, procedures were followed as indicated in embryonic cultures up to the mechanical dispersion and centrifugation steps. Within each microfuge tube, 100 μl Schneider’s medium was added per 45 embryos invested. The tube was then covered with aluminium foil and placed in a vertical position in a 26°C incubator for 3-7 days. After that, the tubes were centrifuged at 650 rcf for 5 min and following this the culture media was removed and discarded (via pipette). 100 μl of dispersion media was then added and cells in the tube were gently dissociated by pipetting up and down. Cells were next incubated for 3 min at 37°C. After, 200 μl of Schneider’s culture media was added to stop the dispersion reaction and centrifuged at 650 rcf for 5 min. The pellet was re-suspended in the final desired volume (30 μl per culture) of culture media and plated on culture chambers. Since neurons grow slower after pre-culture, the chambers were left facing down for 2 hours to promote neurons to attach to the coverslip, and their minimum culture period was 18h at 26°C or 29°C.

sec.title: Antisera and Immunocytochemistry
sec.p: Neuronal cultures were fixed over 30 mins at room temperature (RT) in 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) and 0.05% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.2). For anti-Eb1 staining, cells were fixed for 10 mins at -20°C in +TIP fix (90% methanol, 3% formaldehyde, 5 mM sodium carbonate, pH 9; stored at - 80°C) and added to the cells (Rogers et al., 2002), then washed in PBT (PBS with 0.3% TritonX). For smFISH, cells were fixed 20 minutes at RT with the same fixative and then permeabilised in 70% EtOH for 2 hours up to 2 days at 4°C. Antibody staining and washes were performed with phosphate buffered saline with 0.3% TritonX-100 (PBT). The following primary antibodies were used: anti-Tubulin (rat; 1:500; Sigma); anti-αTub (clone DM1A, mouse, 1:1000, Sigma); anti-GFP antibody (ab6556; rabbit; 1:1000; Abcam); Cy5-or FITC-conjugated anti-HRP (goat; 1:50; Jackson ImmunoResearch); anti-puromycin (mouse; 1:1000; Kerafast); anti-dTBCB (1:500; produced and kindly given by Antoine Guichet (Baffet, Benoit et al. 2012); Eurogentec); anti-DmEb1 (gift from H. Ohkura (Elliott et al., 2005); rabbit, 1:2000) Cy3 (donkey anti-rat; 1:200; Jackson ImmunoResearch), Alexa Fluor® 488 AffinityPure (donkey anti-rabbit; 1:100; and donkey anti-mouse, 1:100; both from Jackson ImmunoResearch); Alexa Fluor® 647 AffinityPure (donkey anti-mouse; 1:100; Jackson ImmunoResearch). As nuclear counterstain, I used 4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI) (5 ng/ml; ThermoFisher). All antisera were diluted in PBT and added to the samples during overnight incubation at 4°C, in case of primary antisera, and 1h30min incubation for secondary antibodies at RT.

sec.title: Puromycin assay
sec.p: For the puromycin assay, I used embryonic cultures as described above but, after 6 HIV, cells were incubated with Schneider’s medium enriched with cychlohexamide (CHX) (300 μg/μl) and puromycin (25 μg/μl) 30 minutes before fixation (Deliu et al., 2017). After fixation (same as described above) and 3 PBT washes, it was stained with anti-Puromycin (mouse; 1:1000; Kerafast) and anti-Tubulin (rat; 1:500; Sigma). After washing, cells were incubated with Alexa Fluor® 488 (mouse, 1:100), Cy3 (rat; 1:200) and Cy5-conjugated HRP (goat; 1:50) as the standard above mentioned protocol.

Puromycin is a product of the bacterium Streptomyces alboniger. It resembles the 3′ end structure of amino-acylated tRNA (aa-tRNA) with a modified adenosine base covalently linked to a tyrosine amino acid (Tercero et al., 1996; Yarmolinsky and Haba, 1959). It incorporates into the C-terminus of elongating nascent peptide chains which results in irreversible premature termination of translation and release of the peptide from ribosomes into the cytoplasm (Semenkov et al., 1992; Starck and Roberts, 2002). Anti-Puromycin staining in the cytoplasm is therefore suggestive of active local translation (Bastide et al., 2018). As a control, cycloheximide (CHX) can be used to shut down active translation, hence also blocking the incorporation of puromycin (Deliu et al., 2017). Our data clearly showed strong puromycin staining evenly throughout axons (rather than in a gradient from the cell body), and this staining was strongly suppressed by cycloheximide (Fig.S10).

sec.title: Imaging and data analysis
sec.p: Neurons were visualised using a compound fluorescence microscope (BX50WI or BX51; Olympus) and images of single neurons were captured using nijiBlueBox and the MatrixVision mvBlueFox3-M2 2124G camera at 100x magnification. Images were analysed using the FIJI/ImageJ 1.54p software: to determine the degree of MT disorganisation in axons we used the “MT disorganisation index” (MDI; Qu et al., 2017): the axon length (from cell body to tip of the most distant microtubule) was measured using the segmented line tool; area of disorganisation was measured using the freehand selection tool; this value was then divided by the the product of axon length multiplied with 0.5 μm (arbitrary axon diameter, thus approximating the expected area of the axon if it were not disorganised); for axon branching data, primary neurites containing a microtubule core of at least 10 µm and branching off the longest neurite were counted. For the Eb1 comet analysis, length and mean intensity of the Eb1 comets was measured using the line tool in FIJI; Eb1 amount was calculated by multiplying comet length with mean intensity (Hahn et al., 2021). All data were normalised against their respective controls. In each experiment, usually three slides per genotype were analysed aiming to image ~30 isolated neurons per slide. Experiments were repeated at least once, data pooled. MDI data were usually not normally distributed but nevertheless plotted as mean ± SEM to avoid misleading median values of zero. Most experiments had only two groups and were assessed using Mann–Whitney Rank Sum tests, experiments with more then two group using Kruskal–Wallis one-way ANOVA with post hoc Dunn’s test. Means of single slides were used to generate super-plots (Lord et al., 2020) and assessed using standard t-tests. Statistical analyses were performed with Graphpad 10.2.2. The data used for our analyses will be made available on request. Image plates were generated with Photoshop CS6 and illustrations with Illustrator CS. Owing to the fact that for many years we have used a standardised, simple and robust system of data management and storage (see details in Prokop, 2021b), we were able to retrieve experimental data and or images obtained in our standardised Drosophila primary neuron system that date back as far as 2009. These were re-analysed to the common standard described above.

sec.title: smFISH analyses
sec.p: But we analysed the abundance of tubulin mRNAs and tubulin proteins. For tubulin mRNA we used single molecule fluorescent in situ hybridisation (smFISH; Orjalo et al., 2011) with specifically designed probes for α1- and β1-tub mRNA; mRNAs were counted along axons where single dots were easy to identify (in contrast to their clustered appearance in cell bodies). In control experiments, depending on culturing strategy and analysis method (see Suppl. Mat.), we counted mean mRNA numbers of 5 to 23 per axon and per tubulin isotype; both α1- and β1-tub smFISH probes proved specific because they showed a stark reduction in number when assessed in neurons deficient for the respective tubulin gene (Pinho-Correia, 2023).

sec.title: Reverse transcription and qRT-PCR analysis
sec.p: To isolate RNA, 30 to 50 third instar larval brains were dissected in PBS and transferred into a tube containing 100 μl Trizol. Larval brains were homogenised with a pestle under the fume hood, 100 μl of chloroform were added and closed tubes were vortexed for a minute, left to incubate at room temperature for 3-5 min and then centrifuged (4°C, 12,000 g, 20 min). 100μl of the upper, clear, RNA- and DNA-containing phase was added to 100 μl pure isopropanol and centrifuged (4°C, 12,000 g, 10 min). The supernatant was discarded and the pellet washed twice with 70% ethanol, adding 400 μl for the first washing step and 250 μl for the second, each step followed by centrifugation (4°C, 12,000 g, 5 min) and discarding the supernatant. The pellet was dried and resuspended in 50-60 μl double-distilled, RNA-free water (ddH2O).

Reverse transcription was carried out using the QuantiTect reverse transcription kit (Qiagen). 500 ng RNA (measured using a NanoDrop by Thermo Scientific according to the manufacturer’s instructions) and 1 μl gDNA wipeout buffer (provided as kit component) were added to 7μl ddH2O in 0.2 ml PCR 8-Strip Tubes (Starlab) and incubated for 2 min at 42°C. 3μl of a mastermix, containing 2 μl Reverse-Transcription-Buffer, 0.5 μl Primer-Mix and 0.5 μl Reverse-Transcriptase were added and the sample was incubated in a thermocycler (Thermal Cycler C1000 by BioRad) for 15 min at 42°C. The Reverse-Transcriptase was then inactivated at 95°C for 3 min. The sample was filled up with 90μl of ddH2O and stored at -20°C.

cDNA samples were analysed using qPCR for which two 20 μl master mixtures were prepared: the first contained 10 μl of SYBRGreen Supermix, including fluorescent dye and 1 μl of 5 μM forward and reverse primer mix (lyophilised primer diluted according to the certificate of synthesis) for the gene in question (see table below). The second was composed of 1 μl cDNA from the stored sample described above and 8 μl ddH2O. The master mixes were prepared in 0.2 ml PCR 8-Strip Tubes and then pipetted into 96 well plates in doublets. The qPCR reaction was carried out using the BioRad® IQ5 Multicolor Real-time PCR detection system. As reference gene we used primers for the RNA of rp49 encoding Ribosomal protein L32 (Hahn et al., 2013).

sec.title: Live imaging procedures
sec.p: For long term imaging, embryos were collected, dechorionated and stage 11 embryos collected by auto-fluorescence pattern. 36 embryos were prepared for primary neuronal cultures (Voelzmann and Sánchez-Soriano, 2022) and cells re-suspended in 200 µl supplemented growth medium. The cell suspension was transferred to a 35mm ConA-coated glass bottom MatTek dish and left to adhere to the dish for 30 minutes. The dish was gently shaken to dislodge non-adhering cells, aspirated and then gently rinsed with 400 uL pre-warmed medium. The medium was then replaced with 3 mL pre-warmed growth medium (to buffer temperature fluctuations, mitigate effects of evaporation) with or without 100 nM SiR-Tubulin. The dish was sealed with Vaseline and a 40 mm coverslip to reduce evaporation of the medium during imaging (Voelzmann and Sánchez-Soriano, 2022). Samples in imaging chambers were transferred to pre-heated imaging chambers and left to equilibrate for 15 minutes.

The long-term live imaging was executed either on a 3I Marianas Yokogawa CSU-X1 spinning disc confocal system with infinite focus stabiliser or a Zeiss LSM880 (Plan Apochromat 63x/1.4 Oil DIC M27 lens) with Definite Focus 2 image stabilisation and environmental chambers. Environmental chambers were pre-heated and equilibrated to 26°C for 45 minutes before samples were added. Samples were left to equilibrate for 15 minutes. Due to the unpredictability of the formation of areas of unbundling and direction of axonal growth, imaging required a large field of view (4x4 tiles or multiposition) while at the same time maintaining sufficient magnification and resolution to identify the formation of areas of microtubule unbundling. Samples were imaged as multi-position 4D stacks for 20 to 22 hours.

The applied imaging setup when using the 3I Marianas Yokogawa microscope: Jupiter-mCherry labelled cells were imaged for ~15 hours as 4D stacks (3 z-planes, 0.34 µm steps) at multiple positions on the MatTek dish with a timelapse interval of 2 minutes, an exposure time of 500ms, 60% laser power (561 nm) and again of 2. On the Zeiss LSM880 microscope, Jupiter-mCherry labelled samples were imaged as image stacks (5 z-planes, 0.35 µm steps) of 16 tiles (4x4) with 3% laser power (561 nm), emission detection at 578-696nm, and 4x line average every 5 minutes. SiR-Tubulin labelled samples were imaged as image stacks (5 z-planes, 0.6 µm steps) of 16 tiles (4x4) with 2% laser power (633 nm), emission detection at 615-695 nm, 2x line average every 5 minutes. Even with definite focus, we noticed a z-shift of ~6 µm over the 19-22 hours imaging period and compensated by adapting the z-stack coordinates.

sec.title: Analysis of live movies
sec.p: Analysis of live movies: 4D stacks were converted to maximum intensity projection time courses. Criteria that were applied for cell analyses were: 1) neurons grew axons at least twice as long as the soma diameter; 2) neurons survived the imaging time course; 3) The entirety of axons stayed in focus and were visible throughout the time course of imaging.

Measuring the size of areas of disorganised MT curling over time: areas of MT unbundling were identified at timepoints when they were most obvious and then traced back to the timepoint of their first initiation which was defined as timepoint 0 for this disorganised region. The area of disorganisation (µm2) was determined in intervals of 30 min and averaged for multiple regions (n = 7 to 26). Due to the variability of the timepoint of curl inititation, the time course gets more data-sparse towards later timepoints.

Onset of disorganisation: to determine the onset of disorganisation, the timepoint of the first appearance of a region of microtubule unbundling was determined relative to the imaging start (~45 minutes after plating primary cultures).

Origin of disorganisation: To determine the origin of disorganisation, regions of disorganisation were traced back to the first unbundling. Unbundling starting at the soma and spreading from there were classed as ‘soma’, unbundling starting at the tip of the growing axon at the time of first appearance were classed as ‘tip’, unbundling starting in the axon shaft classed as ‘shaft’ and unbundling originating during the formation of a branch were classed as ‘branch’. The number of events for each classed was scored.

Number of disorganised regions: The number of unbundled regions along the axon (irrespective of their size) was counted throughout the imaging-lifetime. Only regions on the main extension but not along branches were counted.

caption.p: Examples of MT curling in Drosophila primary neurons. Images show neurons of different genotypes (bottom left; see Tab.S1) cultured for different lengths of time (top right; DIV, days in vitro) and stained for tubulin (green) and the neuronal surface marker HRP (magenta). Cell bodies are indicated by asterisks, axons tips with arrowheads. Yellow boxes demarcate areas of MT-curling and are shown as 2.5-fold magnified greyscale insets (tubulin channel only). Scale bar in A represents 20µm in all images.

The dependency cycle of local axon homeostasis and associated genetic loss-of-function conditions. The centre depicts the dependency cycle of local axon homeostasis (Prokop, 2021a; Smith et al., 2023): (1) axonal transport provides materials and organelles to uphold axonal physiology and function; (2) MT bundles provide the highways for this transport; (3) axonal transport damages MT bundles and causes MT damage including curling; (4) MT-binding proteins (MTBPs) and the axonal cortex are required to maintain MT bundles, thus counterbalancing transport-induced damage; (5) transport-dependent components and physiology are required to uphold MT maintenance machinery. Some components are illustrated around the cycle: act, actin; ER, endoplasmic reticulum; Lys, lysosome; mito, mitochondrion; Mot, motor protein; Msps, Mini spindles (a MT polymerase); Per, peroxisome; ROS, reactive oxygen species; Shot, Short stop (actin-MT linker); Spec, spectrin (cortex component); TBC, tubulin-binding cofactor. Boxes on the outer ring list genetic loss-of-function conditions grouped by protein classes: A1, Scar/WAVE complex; A2, actin nucleation regulators; A3, actin plus end-binding; A4, other actin regulators; A5, cortical actin-regulating or -binding; E1, ROS-regulating; E2, glycolysis component; E3, integrin adhesion components; L, axonal transport cargo linkers; M1, MT plus end-binding; M2, MT lattice-binding; M3, MT severing; M4, MT minus end-binding; Mk, mitotic kinesins; Mo1, mutations causing hyperactivation of kinesin-1 or -3; Mo2, MT-binding transport motors (LOF); Mo3, actin-binding minus-end directed motor (myosin 6); O1, ER-regulating; O2, peroxisome regulating; O3, mitochondrial factors; T1, tubulin chaperones; T2, α/β-tubulin heterodimer-binding; T3, tubulins and tubulin acetylase. Black or grey arrows indicate the degree of MT curling increase (pointing up) or decrease (pointing down; see Tab.S1 for values); colours match those in Tab.S1 and indicate statistical significance as indicated bottom left (* P ≤ 0.05; ** P ≤ 0.01; *** P ≤ 0.001; **** P ≤ 0.0001; see values in Tab.S1).

Illustration summarising published and proposed molecular mechanisms. Image on top illustrates a neuron with a continuous MT bundle (green lines), a pathological swelling with curled MTs. The close-up below shows molecular mechanisms discussed in the main text: (1) hypothesised MT minus-end anchorage to the axonal cortex; (2) Efa6-mediated cortical inhibition of MT polymerisation of MTs that have left the parallel MT bundles and project towards the plasma membrane; (3) the machinery maintaining MT polymerisation: (3a) the scaffold protein Eb1 and MT polymerase Msps mutually maintain their localisation at MT plus ends upholding MT polymerisation, (3b) Tau prevents Eb1 binding to MT lattices preventing its plus-end depletion, (3c) tubulin biogenesis feeds MT polymerisation processes, (3d) cortical actin rings promote MT polymerisation through mechanisms still unknown; (4) Shot-Eb1-mediated guidance of MT extension along the cortex into parallel bundles; (5) Futsch-mediated MT-MT cross-linkage; (6) Katanin-mediated severing of MTs that cross each other; (7) MT zippering to prevent buckling; (8) anterograde transport (here of a mitochondrion); (9) Sod2-mediated catabolism of harmful ROS (O2- to H2O2) within mitochondria potentially signalling to the surrounding cytoplasm; (10) cytoplasmic resistance to cargo transport; (11) cargo-free transport motors detach from MTs in an inactive λ configuration stabilised by factors such as Klc or KIFBP; (12) hypothetical Pigs-mediated guidance of MT extension along central actin filaments.

caption.title: Analysis of origins and expansion of areas of disorganisation in axons.
caption.p: (A) Number of disorganised regions per axon. (B) Onset of axonal disorganisation relative to the imaging start. (C) Origin of disorganised regions in neurons, classified into soma, axon shaft, branch and tip. (D) Development of the total area of disorganisation along axons from the first appearance of disorganised microtubules to the end of the observation period. 0 indicates the first appearance of disorganisation. Neurons from different genetic conditions were adhered to conA-covered imaging chambers for 30 minutes, washed, stained with 100 nM SiRtubulin (where applicable) and acclimatised to 26C. 2 hours after plating, neurons were imaged as multi-tile image stack timeseries. Conditions: Eb1=Eb104524/04524; shot=shot3/3; Klc=Klc8ex94,8ex94; Jup=Jupiter-mCherry.

Loss of actin regulators shows a trend towards reduced MDI and axon elongation. Analyses of different actin regulators; for detailed data and gene information see Tab.S1. Most of the mutant neurons carry strong loss-of-function mutant alleles either in homozygosis (no slash), over a deficiency uncovering the gene in question (allele/Df), or in heteroallelic combination with another strong loss-of-function mutant allele (allele/allele); note that three examples display double-mutant and one example a triple-mutant condition, that sca>RacN17 represents the overexpression of a dominant-negative version of Rac1 in otherwise wild-type mutant background, and that Arpc1 analyses are comparative shown for neurons grown on glass or using concanavalin-A as substrate (conA). (A) MT-curling is measured as MT disorganisation index (MDI; area of MT curling divided by the product of axon length and an assumed axons width of 0.5µm), with bars representing mean ± standard error of mean all normalised to parallel controls (stippled red line); blue dots reflect data for individual neurons, the red circles the means of repeats (usually 20-30 neurons on one coverslip). Blue asterisks indicate the significance of pooled data established using Mann-Whitney tests which is also reflected in the bar colour, and the red asterisks show the significance of repeat means established with t-tests. For bar colours see inset in Fig.2 and asterisks indicate the following values: * P ≤ 0.05; ** P ≤ 0.01; *** P ≤ 0.001; **** P ≤ 0.0001 (see exact values in Tab.S1). (B) Graphs and colour codes for axon length measurements follow the same logic, but data are shown as median and interquartile ranges.

Analysis of chaperones involved in tubulin biogenesis. Analyses of the normalised MDI (A) and normalised axon length (B) presented with the same logic as explained in Fig. 5 (for detailed data see Tab.S1). The suffix ‘-IR’ (interference RNA) in gene names refers to gene knock-down driven by elav-Gal4, with TBCA-D being knocked down with two independent transgenic constructs (indicated by superscript ‘1’ and ‘2’); all other conditions represent loss-of-function mutant alleles or elav-Gal4-driven overexpression of stai. To facilitate reading of this graph, grey boxes in A indicate the different genes manipulated and listed below B. Cultured neurons were either embryo-derived and cultured for 3 days (e3DIV) or derived from larval brains and cultured for 1 day (L3).

caption.title: Summary of all experiments to date using Trolox applications.
caption.p: A) Graph comparing the MT-curling phenotypes of neurons carrying certain loss-of-function mutant conditions (light brown) normalised to untreated control neurons (red stippled horizontal line) and compared to the same mutant condition but treated with 100 nM Trolox applied with the culture medium (see Methods); genetic manipulations on the left side of the vertical line represent either functional loss of MT-binding proteins (indicated by blue dots) or hyperactivation of transport motors (red dots), and manipulations on the right side cause Trolox-rescuable MT-curling which comprises conditions of transport deficiency (black dots), organelle dysfunction (green dots) or the cytoplasmic ROS regulator Sod1 (grey dot). Most data were published previously (Khc, Kif5A, KFBP, Klc, Arl8, milt, unc-104 in Liew et al., 2025; fh, Pdha, SdhA, sesB, Sod2 in Murray-Cors et al., 2025; Sod1 in Shields et al., 2025); details of new data (kat60, Pav, shot, Rtn-Reep) are show in Fig.8. B) Results from A presented in the context of the ‘dependency cycle of local axon homeostasis’ (see Fig.2). Light green box on the left: it contains all genetic manipulations on the left side of the vertical line in A (font colours corresponding to colour of dots in A) which caused MT-curling not rescued by Trolox providing consistent support for the ROS-independent damage-repair imbalance hypothesis (red and blue arrows) referred to as ‘structural homeostasis’ (above box). Light green box on the right: it contains all genetic manipulations on the right of the vertical line in A which cause MT-curl-inducing ROS likely by affecting ‘physiological homeostasis’ (above box).

New experiments assessing MT-curling phenotypes with Trolox. Each graph represents one set of experiments composed of wild-type without Trolox (wt), wt with Trolox (+Trol) and the respective loss-of-function mutant condition (as indicated in C-G) without/with Trolox. Graphs are organised as explained in the legend of Fig.5A. Kruskall-Wallis test results are indicated on top, Dunn’s multiple comparison results are indicated above bars; the intensity of brown fill-colour of bars reflects the degree of statistical significance relative to wild-type control without Trolox.
